{{Infobox economist | name = | school_tradition = | image = File:Vladimir Burkov.jpg | image_size = | caption = Vladimir Burkov | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1939|11|17}} | birth_place = [[Vologda]], [[Russia]] | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = [[Russia]]n | institution = [[V.A. Trapeznikov Institute of Control Sciences of RAS]] | field = [[Game theory]], [[mechanism design]], [[combinatorial optimization]] | alma_mater = [[Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Alexander Lerner]] | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = [[Dmitry Novikov]] | notable_students = | influences = | influenced = | contributions = [[Theory of Active Systems]] | awards = [[State Prize of USSR]]
[[Honorary titles of Russia|Honoured Scholar of the Russian Federation]] | signature = }} '''Vladimir Nikolaevich Burkov''' is a Russian control theorist and the author of more than four hundred publications on control problems, game theory, and combinatorial optimization. Laureate of [[State Prize of USSR]], of Prize of Cabinet Council of USSR, he is a [[Honorary titles of Russia|Honoured Scholar of the Russian Federation]]. Vladimir Burkov is a vice-president of Russian Project Management Association (SOVNET) (the Russian branch of International Project Management Association, IPMA), Member of [[Russian Academy of Natural Sciences]]. A professor at [[Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology]] and Head of Laboratory at V.A. Trapeznikov Institute of Control Sciences of RAS, in the end of 1960s he pioneered the theory of active systems (which was a Soviet version of the theory of [[mechanism design]]). == Biography == Vladimir Burkov was born on November 17, 1939, in the city of [[Vologda]]. In 1963 he graduated from the [[Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology|Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology (MIPT)]] and was employed by Institute of Automation and Remote Control (since 1970s it is known as ICS RAS, V.A. Trapeznikov Institute of Control Sciences of RAS), where he earned his [[Candidate of Sciences]] degree in 1966, and became [[Doctor of Sciences]] in 1975. In 1981 he earned professorship at the Chair of Control Sciences at [[Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology|MIPT]] and since 1974 he works as a Head of Laboratory 57 (Laboratory of active systems) at ICS RAS. Married to Elena Burkova, the couple has a daughter Irina, who also earned the doctoral degree for her contributions to control theory. == Contributions to combinatory optimization and project scheduling == Early academic interests of Vladimir Burkov were connected with applied problems of [[combinatorial optimization]];{{cite book|url=http://www.mtas.ru/search/search_results.php?publication_id=1444|title=Combinatorics and technical progress (Комбинаторика и развитие техники)|first=|publisher=Znaniye (Знание)|year=1968|isbn=|edition=|series=|volume=|location=Moscow (Москва)|page=|pages=|at=|language=Russian|chapter=|format=|quote=|ref=|orig-year=|chapter-url=|via=|issue=|author=Burkov V.N., Lovetsky S.E. (Бурков В.Н., Ловецкий С.Е.)|agency=}}{{Cite journal|last=Burkov V.N. (Бурков В.Н.)|first=|last2=Lovetsky S.E. (Ловецкий С.Е.)|first2=|year=1968|title=Solution techniques for extremal combinatorpal problems: a survey (Методы решения экстремальных задач комбинаторного типа (обзор) )|url=|journal=Automation and Remote Control|language=Russian|volume=11|pages=|via=}}{{cite book|url=|title=Combinatorial programming (Комбинаторное программирование)|first=|last2=Rubinstein M.I. (Рубинштейн М.И.)|publisher=Znaniye (Знание)|year=1977|isbn=|edition=|series=|volume=|location=Moscow (Москва)|page=|pages=|at=|chapter=|format=|quote=|ref=|orig-year=|chapter-url=|via=|issue=|author=Burkov V.N. (Бурков В.Н.)|agency=}} in 1960s he contributed to the boom of [[Scheduling (computing)|project scheduling]] and network planning,{{Cite journal|last=Burkov|first=V.N.|year=1969|title=Optimal project control|url=|journal=in Proc. if 4th IFAC Congress,|publication-place=Warszawa|volume=46|pages=|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Burkov|first=V. N.|last2=Moiseenko|first2=G. Ye.|year=1969|title=Problems of analysis and optimization of complexes of operations during registering transferences of resources|url=https://zbmath.org/?q=an:0274.90062|journal=Avtomat. i Telemekh.|volume=12|pages=86–93|via=ZentralMATH}} proposed novel models of resource allocation in organizations{{Cite journal|last=Burkov|first=V.N.|year=1966|title=Resources allocation as a time optimal problem|url=http://www.mathnet.ru/php/archive.phtml?wshow=paper&jrnid=at&paperid=11140&option_lang=eng|journal=Avtomat. i Telemekh.|volume=7|pages=119–129|via=MathNet}} and in technical systems,{{Cite journal|last=Burkov|first=V.N.|last2=Sokolov|first2=V.B.|year=1969|title=Optimal information allocation in the magnetic tape memory for bidirectional search|url=|journal=Avtomat. i Telemekh.|volume=4|pages=107–117|via=ZentralMATH}} solved several extremal graph problems.{{Cite journal|last=Burkov|first=V.N.|last2=Lovetskiĭ|first2=S.E.|year=1965|title=Maximal flow through a generalized transport network|url=http://www.ams.org/mathscinet-getitem?mr=201196|journal=Avtomat. i Telemekh.|volume=26:12|pages=2163–2169|via=MathSciNet}}{{Cite journal|last=Burkov|first=V.N.|last2=Groppen|first2=V.O.|year=1974|title=Solving the problem of minimal cut on a bi-connected orgraph by the branch-and-bound method|url=http://www.mathnet.ru/php/archive.phtml?wshow=paper&jrnid=at&paperid=8485&option_lang=eng|journal=Avtomat. i Telemekh.|volume=9|pages=104–110|via=MathNet}} In particular, Vladimir Burkov proposed a lower-bound estimate{{Cite journal|last=Burkov|first=V.N.|year=1972|title=Problems of optimum distribution of resources|url=http://www.mtas.ru/search/search_results.php?publication_id=854|journal=Control and cybernetics|volume=1|issue=1-2|pages=27–41|via=mtas.ru}} of the project makespan in [[Scheduling (computing)|resource-constrained project scheduling problem]] re-invented in 1998 by A. Mingozzi et al.{{Cite journal|last=Mingozzi A., Maniezzo V., Ricciardelli S., Bianco L.|first=|year=1998|title=An exact algorithm for project scheduling with resource constraints based on new mathematical formulation|url=http://dl.acm.org/citation.cfm?id=293907|journal=Management Science|volume=44|pages=714–729|via=ACM|doi=10.1287/mnsc.44.5.714}} Two books by Vladimir Burkov, "Network models and control problems"{{cite book|url=|title=Networks Models and Control Problems (Сетевые модели и задачи управления)|first=|publisher=Sovetskoye Radio (Советское радио)|year=1967|isbn=|edition=|series=|volume=|location=Moscow (Москва)|page=|pages=|at=|language=Russian|chapter=|format=|quote=|ref=|orig-year=|chapter-url=|via=|issue=|author=Burkov V.N., Landa B.D., Lovetsky S.E., Teiman A.I. (Бурков В.Н., Ланда Б.Д., Ловецкий С.Е., Тейман А.И.)|agency=}} and "Applied problems of graph theory" {{cite book|url=|title=Applied problems of graph theory (Прикладные задачи теории графов)|first=|publisher=Metsniereba (Мецниереба)|year=1974|isbn=|edition=|series=|volume=|location=Tbilisi (Тбилиси)|page=|pages=|at=|chapter=|format=|quote=|ref=|orig-year=|chapter-url=|via=|issue=|author=Burkov V.N., Gorgidze I.A., Lovetsky S.E. (Бурков В.Н., Горгидзе И.А., Ловецкий С.Е.)|agency=}} put forward the problems being intensively studied until now. == Launching theory of active systems == Since late 1960s interests of Vladimir Burkov shift to the studies of specific nature of human being as a controlled object (an agent). In 1969 he pursued an idea of the "''fairplay principle''" (in Russian: принцип открытого управления): plans assigned to selfish agents by the optimal control mechanism must be coordinated with agents' goal functions. Under such an [[incentive-compatible]] mechanism truthtelling is benefitiary for agents.{{Cite journal|last=Burkov|first=V.N.|last2=Lerner|first2=A.Ya.|year=1970|title=Open control principle for active systems|url=https://zbmath.org/?q=an:0218.93003|journal=Avtomat. i Telemekh.|volume=8|pages=100–111|via=ZentralMATH}}{{cite book| author = Burkov V.N., Lerner A.Ya. | chapter = | chapter-url = | format = | url = http://www.mtas.ru/search/search_results.php?publication_id=856 | title = Fairplay in control of active systems | orig-year = | agency = H. W. Kuhn and G. P. Szego, eds. | edition = Differential games and related topics |location= Amsterdam, London |year= 1971 |publisher= North-Holland Publishing Company |at= |volume= |issue = | pages = 164–168| page = | series = | isbn = | ref = }} The notion of [[incentive compatibility]] was independently proposed by [[Leonid Hurwicz|Leonid Hurwitz]],{{cite book| author = Hurwicz L. | chapter = | chapter-url = | format = | url = | title = On informationally decentralized systems | orig-year = | agency = C. B. McGuire and R. Radner, eds. | edition = Decision and Organization: a Volume in Honor of Jacob Marshak |location= Amsterdam, London |year= 1972 |publisher= North-Holland Publishing Company |at= |volume= |issue = | pages = 297–336| page = | series = | isbn = | ref = }} and later was extended and elaborated by [[Allan Gibbard]],{{Cite journal|last=Gibbard|first=Allan|year=1973|title=Manipulation of voting schemes: A general result|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0022053176900168|journal=Econometrica|volume=41|pages=587–601|via=Science Direct|doi=10.2307/1914083}} [[Roger Myerson]],{{Cite journal|last=Myerson|first=Roger|year=1979|title=Incentive compatibility and the bargaining problem|url=http://econpapers.repec.org/article/ecmemetrp/v_3a47_3ay_3a1979_3ai_3a1_3ap_3a61-73.htm|journal=Econometrica|volume=47|pages=61–74|via=EconPaper|doi=10.2307/1912346}} and many other researchers. They pioneered the [[revelation principle]], which opened a new era in the studies of economic institutions ([[mechanism design]] and [[contract theory]]); it was mentioned as the main achievement{{Cite web|url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/economic-sciences/laureates/2007/advanced-economicsciences2007.pdf|title=Mechanism Design Theory: Scientific background on the Sveriges Riksbank Prize in Economic Sciences in Memory of Alfred Nobel 2007|last=Compiled by the Prize Committee of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}} in 2007s [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]] won by [[Leonid Hurwicz|L. Hurwitz]], [[Eric Maskin|E. Maskin]], and [[Roger Myerson|R. Myerson]]. The fairplay principle became the foundation of the newly introduced ''theory of active systems'' (a version of mechanism design originated from USSR), which systematically studied control mechanisms in man-machine systems. In 1970s the seminal books and articles{{Cite journal|last=Burkov|first=V.N.|last2=Kondrat'yev|first2=V.V.|year=1977|title=Two-level active systems. I. Basic notions and definitions|url=http://www.ams.org/mathscinet-getitem?mr=469369|journal=Avtomat. i Telemekh.|volume=7|pages=62–70|via=MathSciNet}}{{Cite journal|last=Burkov|first=V.N.|last2=Kondrat'yev|first2=V.V.|year=1977|title=Two-level active systems. II. Analysis and synthesis of functioning mechanisms|url=http://www.ams.org/mathscinet-getitem?mr=469370|journal=Avtomat. i Telemekh.|volume=7|pages=62–70|via=MathSciNet}}{{Cite journal|last=Burkov|first=V.N.|last2=Kondrat'yev|first2=V.V.|year=1977|title=Two-level active systems. III. Equilibria in above-board control laws|url=http://www.ams.org/mathscinet-getitem?mr=534771|journal=Avtomat. i Telemekh.|volume=9|pages=83–91|via=MathSciNet}}{{Cite journal|last=Burkov|first=V.N.|last2=Enaleev|first2=A.K.|last3=Kondrat'yev|first3=V.V.|year=1980|title=Two-level active systems. IV. Price of decentralizing functioning mechanisms|url=http://www.mathnet.ru/php/archive.phtml?wshow=paper&jrnid=at&paperid=7112&option_lang=eng|journal=Avtomat. i Telemekh.|volume=6|pages=110–117|via=MathNet}}{{Cite journal|last=Burkov|first=V.N.|last2=Enaleev|first2=A.K.|last3=Kondrat'yev|first3=V.V.|last4=Tsvetkov|first4=A.V.|year=1983|title=Elements of the theory of optimal design for functioning mechanisms of two-level active systems. I|url=https://zbmath.org/?q=an:0542.90046|journal=Avtomat. i Telemekh.|volume=10|pages=139–143|via=ZentralMATH}} determined the directions of theory development for many decades to come (some books of early 2010s are {{cite book| author = Burkov V., Goubko M., Kondrat’ev V., Korgin N., Novikov D. | chapter = | chapter-url = | format = | url = http://www.mtas.ru/search/search_results.php?publication_id=19038 | title = Mechanism Design and Management: Mathematical Methods for Smart Organizations (for managers, academics and students) | orig-year = | agency = | edition = |location= New York |year= 2013 |publisher= Nova Publishers |at= |volume= |issue = | pages = | page = | series = | isbn = | ref = }}{{cite book| author = Novikov D. | chapter = | chapter-url = | format = | url = | title = Theory of Control in Organizations | orig-year = | agency = | edition = |location= New York |year= 2013 |publisher= Nova Science Publishers |at= |volume= |issue = | pages = | page = 341 | series = | isbn = 978-1624177941| ref = }}{{cite book| author = Burkov V. N., Goubko M., Korgin N., Novikov D. | chapter = | chapter-url = | format = | url = http://www.mtas.ru/search/search_results_ubs_new.php?publication_id=19852&IBLOCK_ID=10 | title = Introduction to Theory of Control in Organizations | orig-year = | agency = | edition = |location= Boca Raton |year= 2015 |publisher= CRC Press |at= |volume= |issue = | pages = | page = | series = | isbn = | ref = }}). == Organizational and teaching activities == In 1973 V. Burkov headed the newly created division in the Institute of Automation and Remote Control called "the Sector of Business Games"; in 1974 it was re-organized into the Laboratory 57 "Theory and methods of business games" later renamed to "Laboratory of Active Systems". As of the end of 2016 its headcount is 28 employees including 15 [[Doctor of Sciences|Doctors of Sciences]] and 5 [[Candidate of Sciences|Candidates of Sciences]]. During the decades V. Burkov superwised dozens of thesis works.{{Cite web|url=http://mtas.ru/users/chart/|title=Interactive tree of the Theory of Active Systems|last=|first=|date=|publisher=|access-date=|author=|work=}} == Famous followers == Professor Dmitry Novikov, corresponding member of [[Russian Academy of Sciences]] (since 2008), was elected a director of ICS RAS on October 17, 2016. == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Burkov, Vladimir}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Mathematicians]] [[Category:Control theorists]]

{{unreferenced|date=August 2012}} '''Warsaw School of Mathematics''' is the name given to a group of [[mathematician]]s who worked at [[Warsaw]], [[Poland]], in the two decades between the World Wars, especially in the fields of [[logic]], [[set theory]], [[point-set topology]] and [[real analysis]]. They published in the journal ''[[Fundamenta Mathematicae]]'', founded in 1920—one of the world's first specialist [[mathematics journal|pure-mathematics journals]]. It was in this journal, in 1933, that [[Alfred Tarski]]—whose illustrious career would a few years later take him to the [[University of California, Berkeley]]—published his celebrated theorem on the [[undefinability of the notion of truth]].
Notable members of the Warsaw School of Mathematics have included: * [[Wacław Sierpiński]] * [[Kazimierz Kuratowski]] * [[Edward Marczewski]] * [[Bronisław Knaster]] * [[Zygmunt Janiszewski]] * [[Stefan Mazurkiewicz]] * [[Stanisław Saks]] * [[Karol Borsuk]] * [[Roman Sikorski]] * [[Nachman Aronszajn]] * [[Samuel Eilenberg]]
Additionally, notable logicians of the [[Lwów-Warsaw School of Logic]], working at [[Warsaw]], have included: * [[Stanisław Leśniewski]] * [[Adolf Lindenbaum]] * [[Alfred Tarski]] * [[Jan Łukasiewicz]] * [[Andrzej Mostowski]] * [[Helena Rasiowa]]
Fourier analysis has been advanced at [[Warsaw]] by: * [[Aleksander Rajchman]] * [[Antoni Zygmund]] * [[Józef Marcinkiewicz]] * [[Otton M. Nikodym]] * [[Jerzy Spława-Neyman]]
==See also== * [[Polish School of Mathematics]] * [[Kraków School of Mathematics]] * [[Lwów School of Mathematics]]
{{warsaw-stub}} {{math-stub}}
